text: uh hi everyone real fanny phil tano here
the internet's busiest music nerd i hope
you're doing well and it's time for a
review of the new godspeed album
godspeed at states and
uh this is a brand new lp from legendary
post and instrumental rock outfit
godspeed you black emperor
the band's music has long served as the
soundtrack to the west's
and capitalism's merciless pillage of
the world around it
the band is responsible for what are
some of my favorite records of all time
lift your skinny fists slow riot for new
zero
which is why back in the day i was sad
to have come into the band's music as
they were
well into their multi-year hiatus they
started in 2003
but then eventually i was excited to see
the band make a triumphant return at the
start of the 2010s with
killer reunion shows their fourth
full-length record
alleluia don't bend ascend which is an
excellent lp
highly recommend it rarely are comeback
records this good
but in my opinion at least the band
started to see
diminishing returns the further they
went into this new chapter of their
career
i felt 2015's asunder was merely
passable the bare minimum of what a
godspeed record should be then
luciferian towers a few years later
is easily my least favorite work of
theirs to date
the new lps just seem to be on this
disappointing trend where the
instrumental crescendos aren't quite as
grand the
finer details aren't quite there either
there also seems to be less of an
emphasis overall on experimentation
drones the
creative use of field recordings that
have been a trademark characteristic of
the band over the years
and i get i can't just expect godspeed
to artistically
do the same thing forever again and
again and again on each new record but
i don't really feel like we've been
getting a new direction as much as we've
been getting a lesser version
and while i really had no reason to
expect things would get much better on
this latest project
i will say after witnessing some of the
most hellish years in this country's
existence in my lifetime
nothing sounds better than some
dystopian anarchohymnals to
wash it all down now like many godspeed
records as of late
this thing is mostly centered around two
very lengthy
pieces two shorter pallet cleansers
first the 20 minute a military alphabet
following that the six minute fire at
static valley
then follows the next major piece on the
record government came also 20 minutes
in length
and then our side has to win closes up
shop after that
the larger pieces of course work in
multiple phases and
honestly i'm a little torn between both
of them there are points where a
military alphabet feels like it's trying
to squander
every bit of potential that it has which
is unfortunate because the whole thing
kicks off with this very mysterious
textured sloshy field recording passage
it sounds like lost transmissions and
radio static this is a vibe i haven't
quite heard from the band in a while
something i'm sort of excited to see
return but ultimately there's not really
much in terms of a core
sound or message that translates through
all of it
eventually it quickly gives way to an
instrumental passage that
essentially sounds like the band kind of
tuning up the next movement on the track
sees a gentle build up which is a good
sign for any godspeed song but it seems
the end goal of this cut is to deliver
this
very average mid-paced riff and just
slowly thicken it up with
more bass and strings honestly it feels
like luciferian towers all over again
except maybe this time there are some
subtly psychedelic rhythm guitars
sloshing away in the mix
some tangy organ cords hitting on every
other beat too
it's like we're suddenly getting a
60-site garage flare to godspeed sound
in this
chapter of their discography once the
instrumental palette of this passage is
established the track doesn't really go
anywhere all that surprising
frankly it finishes in a way that would
have just been too obvious had the band
been writing and recording this piece
20 years ago but for as much as i
complain i actually wish this part just
coasted out for the rest of the piece
because
it's actually a lot more preferable to
the next movement first of the last
glaciers
which yeah does kick off like a total
slugfest in the first minute
but the slower tempo ghoulish guitar
melodies and fiddles that follow make me
feel like i'm listening to a
bad combination of post rock country and
novelty halloween music but really the
following interlude track fire at static
valley the five minutes and 58 seconds
of this piece is more compelling than
all of the 20 minutes that just
transpired with
the previous cut i love the slow ominous
steady kick drums on this track
the chilling dirty melodies soaked in
delay the looming layers of strings that
melt into the supremely dark chord
progression
it's enveloping it's haunting as
godspeed's best stuff tends to be
now the next major movement on this lp
government came i actually loved quite a
bit i think it's one of the band's best
pieces since alleluia
sonically it may not be as dynamic as
the old stuff but it still courses
through this linear and organic
progression of
crunchy bass riffs weepy string melodies
heart-wrenching guitar leads the whole
piece is a truly tragic awe-inspiring
ascent that feels like
the whole world's spiraling down into
hell but by contrast
the next section the cliffs gaze section
of this piece
brings things into an uplifting
direction with warm
hopeful anthemic folk inspired lead
melodies that
just soar over all of the grand rock
instrumentation
it's like the whole piece in this album
are seeing a moment of redemption of
some sort following this the track our
side has to win is like a droney dreamy
finisher
very soft on the ears and while i did
find some sections of this lp pretty
underwhelming in the first leg
i think the project ties up very nicely
really in my opinion godspeed's best lp
since they came back with alleluia
and you know what even though it is
lacking in some respects
as far as the current field of post rock
goes i can't think of too many
